name: Göbekli Tepe
description: The world's oldest known temple complex, featuring T‑shaped limestone pillars carved by hunter‑gatherers.

name: Stonehenge
description: A prehistoric stone circle precisely aligned with the solstices, likely used for ceremonial astronomy.

name: Chichen Itza
description: A Maya city dominated by the Pyramid of Kukulkan, whose shadow forms a serpent during equinoxes.

name: Angkor Wat
description: The largest religious monument on Earth, originally a Hindu temple later transformed into a Buddhist shrine.

name: Teotihuacan
description: A vast pre‑Aztec metropolis famed for the Pyramids of the Sun and Moon and a rigid grid avenue plan.

name: Valley of the Kings
description: Hidden necropolis of Egypt’s New Kingdom rulers, including Tutankhamun’s intact tomb.

name: Newgrange
description: A Neolithic passage tomb that fills with sunlight at dawn on the winter solstice.

name: Nabta Playa
description: One of the world’s earliest astronomical sites, a stone circle in the Nubian Desert tracking stellar rising points.

name: Mohenjo‑Daro
description: An Indus Valley city with baked‑brick houses, covered drains, and the Great Bath.

name: Tikal
description: Maya super‑power with towering limestone pyramids rising above the rainforest canopy.

name: Ziggurat of Ur
description: A stepped Sumerian temple erected for the moon‑god Nanna, later restored by Nabonidus and Saddam Hussein.

name: Giza Pyramid
description: The Great Pyramid of Khufu, the last surviving Wonder of the Ancient World.

name: Saqqara Step Pyramid
description: The world’s first large‑scale stone structure, built for Pharaoh Djoser by Imhotep.

name: Abu Simbel
description: Twin rock temples carved for Ramses II, relocated in the 1960s to save them from Lake Nasser.

name: Petra
description: Nabatean caravan‑city whose façades are carved into rose‑red sandstone cliffs.

name: Machu Picchu
description: Inca royal estate perched on an Andean ridge, rediscovered by Hiram Bingham.

name: Karnak
description: A colossal temple complex built over 2,000 years, aligned to the midwinter sunrise.

name: Nazca Lines
description: Hundreds of geoglyphs—including hummingbirds and spiders—etched into the Peruvian desert.

name: Serpent Mound
description: A 400‑meter earthen effigy snake aligned to solstices and lunar standstills.

name: Great Zimbabwe
description: Medieval stone city with soaring dry‑stone enclosures and conical tower.

name: Yonaguni Monument
description: Submerged terraces off Japan debated as natural or man‑made ruins.

name: Puma Punku
description: Bolivian platform of precisely cut andesite blocks that fit together like jigsaw pieces.

name: Tiwanaku
description: Capital of a pre‑Incan civilization famed for monolithic gateways near Lake Titicaca.

name: Gunung Padang
description: Indonesian hill hiding buried megalithic layers possibly older than Göbekli Tepe.

name: Mount Kailash
description: Sacred Himalayan peak revered as the axis mundi in multiple religions.

name: Atlantis
description: Legendary island civilization described by Plato, widely speculated to lie near the Azores.

name: Banpo
description: Neolithic village near Xi’an with defensive ditch and matriarchal dwellings.

name: Sanxingdui
description: Chinese Bronze Age site yielding alien‑like bronze masks and statues.

name: Monte Albán
description: Zapotec capital built atop a leveled mountain with ballcourts and tombs.

name: La Danta
description: One of the world’s largest pyramids by volume, buried in Guatemala’s El Mirador basin.

name: Çatalhöyük
description: A densely packed Neolithic settlement with wall‑to‑wall houses and mural art.

name: Hattusa
description: Hittite capital famed for its Lion Gate and cuneiform archives.

name: Dendera
description: Temple complex dedicated to Hathor with vivid astronomical ceiling.

name: Lothal
description: Indus port city with a sophisticated dockyard and bead workshops.

name: Harappa
description: Major Indus Valley urban center noted for standardized bricks.

name: Mehrgarh
description: One of the earliest farming communities in South Asia.

name: Dholavira
description: Indus city with massive reservoirs and sophisticated water engineering.

name: Sanchi
description: Buddhist stupa complex commissioned by Emperor Ashoka.

name: Ellora
description: Rock‑cut cave complex representing Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain faiths.

name: Baalbek
description: Roman Heliopolis with Jupiter Temple built from some of the largest stone blocks ever quarried.

name: Hypogeum of Ħal‑Saflieni
description: A subterranean Neolithic necropolis in Malta, famous for its acoustic 'oracle' chamber and red‑ochre wall art.

name: Tarxien Temples
description: A complex of four megalithic temples with spiral carvings and stone altars, among the last built on prehistoric Malta.

name: Nan Madol
description: A ruined city of basalt islets and canals off Pohnpei, once the ceremonial center of the Saudeleur dynasty.

name: Cahokia Mounds
description: The largest pre‑Columbian settlement north of Mexico, crowned by the massive earthen Monks Mound.

name: Timgad
description: A Roman colonial city in Algeria laid out in a perfect grid, later buried by Sahara sands.

name: Knossos
description: Bronze Age palace complex on Crete linked to the legend of the Minotaur and the Labyrinth.

name: Troy
description: Multi‑layered city mound associated with Homer’s Trojan War, excavated by Schliemann.

name: Caral
description: One of the oldest urban centers in the Americas, featuring sunken plazas and platform mounds.

name: Eridu
description: Considered the first city in Mesopotamia, sacred to the god Enki and home to successive mud‑brick temples.

name: Ubar
description: The fabled 'Atlantis of the Sands', rediscovered via satellite imagery in Oman’s Empty Quarter.

name: Skara Brae
description: A remarkably preserved Neolithic village on Orkney, complete with stone furniture.

name: Chavín de Huántar
description: Andean pilgrimage center with labyrinthine galleries and feline‑deity carvings.

name: Sipán Tomb
description: Elite Moche burial revealing a 'Lord of Sipán' adorned with gold and turquoise.

name: Nok Terracottas
description: Site where enigmatic terracotta sculptures signaled one of Africa’s earliest complex cultures.

name: Igbo‑Ukwu
description: Nigerian village that yielded intricate bronze and copper castings of unmatched medieval quality.

name: Mapungubwe
description: Hilltop capital of a southern African kingdom that traded with India and China.

name: Kilwa Kisiwani
description: Swahili city‑state whose coral‑rag palaces testify to medieval Indian Ocean trade wealth.

name: Old Dongola
description: Christian Nubian capital on the Nile later transformed into a Muslim town.

name: Ain Ghazal
description: Neolithic mega‑village near Amman known for its two‑meter human statues.

name: Tall el‑Hammam
description: Archaeological mound some scholars link to the biblical city of Sodom, destroyed by sudden blast.

name: Derinkuyu Underground City
description: A sprawling multi‑level underground refuge in Cappadocia capable of sheltering thousands during raids.

name: Persepolis
description: Ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire, built by Darius I with grand terrace and Apadana halls.

name: Palmyra
description: Caravan oasis city in Syria blending Greco‑Roman and Persian architecture, famed for its colonnaded street.

name: Mount Nemrut
description: Torrent‑top mausoleum of King Antiochus I, ringed by giant seated deities and a collapsed pyramid mound.

name: Luxor Temple
description: Sandstone temple aligned with Karnak, host to Opet Festival processions and colossal Ramesses II statues.

name: Borobudur
description: A nine‑terrace Buddhist mandala rising from Java, adorned with 2,672 relief panels and 504 Buddhas.

name: Lalibela Rock‑Hewn Churches
description: Monolithic Ethiopian churches carved top‑down into red tuff, linked by tunnels and trenches.

name: Bagan Temples
description: A plain studded with over 2,000 brick and gilded stupas built by Burmese kings along the Irrawaddy.

name: Prambanan
description: A towering Hindu trimurti temple complex showcasing ornate bas‑reliefs of the Ramayana.

name: Ajanta Caves
description: Series of rock‑cut Buddhist sanctuaries and paintings illustrating Jataka tales and early Gupta art.

name: Qal'at al‑Bahrain
description: Tell containing Dilmun’s capital, fortifications, temples, and a Greek garrison layer.

name: Tell es‑Sultan (Jericho)
description: Mound with evidence of the world’s earliest city fortifications and Pre‑Pottery Neolithic towers.

name: Çayönü
description: A Neolithic Anatolian village showing transition to agriculture and possible skull cult practices.

name: Lepenski Vir
description: Mesolithic riverside settlement with trapezoidal houses and enigmatic fish‑shaped sculptures.

name: Carnac Stones
description: Alignment of over 3,000 standing stones stretching for kilometers in Brittany, purpose still debated.

name: Maeshowe
description: A solstice‑aligned chambered tomb on Orkney containing Viking runic graffiti.

name: Carahunge
description: An Armenian megalithic field dubbed 'Armenia’s Stonehenge', with holes likely for star sighting.

name: Sigiriya
description: A sky‑palace fortress atop a granite plug featuring frescoes and mirror wall inscriptions.

name: Dolmens of Antequera
description: Three megalithic burial chambers—including Menga—aligned to mountain landmarks.

name: Templo Mayor
description: Aztec twin‑shrine temple uncovered beneath modern Mexico City’s Zócalo.

name: Qenko
description: A limestone amphitheater near Cusco carved with channels for chicha and subterranean passages for Inca rites.

name: Isla del Sol
description: Sacred island on Lake Titicaca where Inca legend says the sun was born.

name: Kuelap
description: Chachapoya hilltop fortress with massive limestone walls and circular dwellings high in the Peruvian Andes.

name: Piquillacta
description: A Wari administrative city laid out in a strict grid overlooking the Lucre Basin.

name: Kalasasaya
description: Sunken temple at Tiwanaku aligned to solstices, featuring the Gate of the Sun.

name: Tazumal
description: Largest Maya site in El Salvador with stepped pyramids and tombs of elite lords.

name: Khao Chan Ngam
description: Prehistoric Thai cliff carvings forming a solar calendar tracking equinoxes.

name: Sunda Pyramid
description: Controversial megalithic mound in West Java proposed to conceal the world’s oldest pyramid.

name: Proto‑Giza Complex
description: Hypothetical earlier phase beneath Giza Plateau suggested by geophysical anomalies.

name: Burial Mound X
description: A newly discovered Viking Age mound in Østfold yielding ornate weapons and horse burials.

name: Sechin Bajo
description: One of the Americas’ oldest monumental complexes, featuring a 5,500‑year‑old circular plaza.

name: Khatt Shebib
description: An enigmatic 150‑km dry‑stone wall in Jordan whose builders and function remain uncertain.

name: AlUla
description: Oasis region with Nabataean tombs at Hegra, rock art, and ancient Dadanite inscriptions.

name: Qatna
description: Bronze Age Syrian palace city boasting rich tombs with lapis‑laden grave goods.

name: Rapa Nui Quarry
description: The volcanic crater where the islanders carved unfinished moai before transport.

name: Enkomi
description: Cypriot Bronze Age city linked to copper trade, later refortified by 'Sea Peoples'.

name: Oyo‑Ile
description: Ruined capital of the Oyo Empire featuring earthen ramparts and royal courts.

name: Tierradentro
description: Colombian park with polychrome‑painted underground tombs and shaft entrances.

name: La Quemada
description: Hilltop fortress in Zacatecas possibly guarding northern trade routes.

name: Atlit Yam
description: Submerged Neolithic village off Israel’s coast, preserved with wells and stone semicircles.
